content: Tyson Foods Inc   the No. 1 U.S. meat processor  said on Tuesday it would buy packaged sandwich supplier AdvancePierre Foods Holdings Inc  for about $3.2 billion in cash  to expand its fast-growing portfolio of prepared food brands. | Video

content: NEW YORK (Reuters Breakingviews) - Tyson Foods has found a delectable new bite to swallow in its quest to become America’s premier protein provider from the farmyard to the kitchen table. Its $3.2 billion purchase of ready-to-eat sandwich maker AdvancePierre takes the Springdale  Arkansas-based poultry company further up the food value chain. Along with plans to carve off some less wholesome morsels  Tyson is giving investors plenty to cluck about.
name: Tyson Foods Inc
title: Tyson makes shareholders tasty $3.2 bln sandwich

content: NEW YORK Traders took a big bite out of AdvancePierre Foods Holdings'  near-term bullish options just days ahead of Tuesday's announcement by Tyson Foods  that it would buy the packaged sandwich supplier for $3.2 billion.

title: U.S. top court rules against Tyson Foods in class action case

content: Aug 14 Tyson Foods Inc on Friday said it is permanently ceasing beef production at its plant in Denison  Iowa  effective immediately  as cattle ranchers work to rebuild shrunken herds following the severe Midwestern drought.
name: Tyson Foods Inc
title: UPDATE 2-Tyson cuts beef production due to cattle shortage

content: Aug 14 Tyson Foods Inc said it will cut beef production capacity due to a shortage of cattle and will close beef operations at its plant in Denison  Iowa  effective Friday.
name: Tyson Foods Inc
title: Tyson to cut beef production due to cattle shortage

content: Tyson Foods Inc   the biggest U.S. meat processor  cut its full-year profit forecast after posting its slowest sales growth in nine quarters as customers overseas refused to accept shipments delayed by West Coast port disruptions. | Video
name: Tyson Foods Inc
title: Tyson sales growth slows as port disruptions hit beef exports

content: Aug 3 Tyson Foods Inc  the biggest U.S. meat processor  warned it may not be able to achieve its profit forecast for the year ending September due to export disruptions in its beef business and high cattle costs.

content: CHICAGO A suspected case of avian influenza has been identified in poultry in Arkansas  the third-largest U.S. turkey producer and home to Tyson Foods Inc  the nation's biggest chicken company  the U.S. Department of Agriculture said on Tuesday.    The infection  if confirmed  threatens to widen trading restrictions from countries such as Taiwan  Singapore and Nicaragua that have already limited U.S. poultry exports due to bird flu outbreaks in states ranging from Minnesota and Misso | Video

title: Suspected bird flu in Arkansas poultry threatens exports
